captions.text: How to become the British Monarch:

Historically, the crown sat upon your head
mostly because you had the biggest army. When

you died usually your eldest son kept control
over that army and so the crown relocated

to his head, though, of course, someone with
a bigger army could change the political landscape
quite abruptly.

As time marched on and the world grew less
violent eventually in 1701 Parliament established

a set of rules to transfer the crown from
one head to another -- hopefully with less
turmoil than before.
So here's how the 1701 rules work:
Frist: don't be Catholic.

The British Monarch is also the head of the
Church of England to which the monarch much

convert if not already a member. Except that
if you're Catholic, no crown for you.

The history of the royal family and how this
rule came to be is a story for another time,

but suffice it to say that bigger-army diplomacy
was involved.

And, BTW, no you can't cleverly get around
this rule by converting from Catholicism to

something else then to Church of England.
In the eyes of the crown, Catholicism is transitive.
Second: don't be a bastard.

Sometimes it's good to be the king, but it's
never good to be the illegitimate children

of the king -- who are out of line for the
crown literally from the moment of their conception.

If you're related to the monarch but are either
a Catholic or a bastard or both, the crown

has the delightful term 'Naturally Dead' to
refer to you and your lack of right to succession.
Third spouses don't count.

While people often think of kings and queens
as a pair: that's not the way it works here.

Spouses of Monarchs are known as Royal Consorts.
They may be called 'prince' or 'queen' but

as far as the crown is concerned, they're
not in line for the throne, they're just the

matching 23 Chromosomes needed for the creation
of the real heir.
Fourth and Finally: Male Primogeniture (whatever).

This is the algorithm of inheritance. When
the Monarch dies -- or abdicates -- but usually

dies -- the crown goes to the eldest son who
isn't 'naturally dead'. If there happens to

be an elder daughter tough luck to her: baby
brother gets the crown.

It's Simple enough, but there are non-obvious
cases: take a king with two sons: if the eldest

dies before the king does, obviously the crown
goes to the youngest (now oldest) brother.

But what if the eldest son gave the king a
grandson before death? Where does the crown
go then?

Well, the crown basically pretends that everyone
-- except the naturally dead -- is alive:

so upon the death of the king the crown goes
to his eldest son -- who is now sort of the

king who just really happens to be dead -- so
the rule kicks in again, and the crown goes

to *his* son, not as seems obvious now, his
brother.

But if this 1701 rule means that eldest sons
get the crown, how did queens ever come to

be? Basically, daughters were the last choice
of the crown, which is why there have been
so few.

To get the crown, a daughter had to be either
the only child of the monarch or the eldest
child without competing brothers.

So pregnant mothers must have made any daughters
with queenly aspirations quite nervous.

Now sometimes the branch of a family tree
die out: be it from war or plague or whatever

so the crown's contingency plan if it's at
a dead end is to back up one level, and then

apply the rules forward again looking for
a living head to sit upon. If no luck, back

up again, and repeat and repeat until a living
heir is found.

And there will always be an heir. The first
king of England was over a thousand years

ago and the mathematics of human reproduction
backed up by DNA evidence reveals that just

about every European alive is distantly related
to him. So the crown will eventually find
a way.

So from the first king through the new millennium,
the various rules when along, making monarchs,

though with a gender biased result, that no
one seemed too bothered about until suddenly,

in 2013 for no particular reason at all, everyone
decided that the rules needed to be updated
*right now*.

So, Parliament and the Monarchy got together
and made some changes: most notably striking
the male part of rule #4.

From 2013 on the crown views all royal sons
and daughters with equal favor. The only thing
that matters is the order of their birth.

So prior to 2013 the boy in a set of fraternal
twins in development could sit back and relax

-- secure that the crown would be his no matter
what happened on delivery day, but in the

post 2013 gender-equal world it's now a race
for the door to win the crown.

title: How to Become the British Monarch

Hanover, a granddaughter of King James I, as per the Act of Settlement. 
Currently, people who marry Catholics (as per the Succession to the Crown 
Act 2013) will not be excluded from the order of succession, but Catholics 
are, also if you are the first six people in the line of succession you 
must ask for consent from The Queen for your marriage.﻿

comments.author: ThankfulCheese1

comments.text:
You know what's funny? Progressives hailing the change to primogeniture 
(allowing eldest females to inherit the throne) when the very idea of a 
monarchy goes against the progressive philosophy of equalism. Shouldn't 
these progs and radical feminists be saying "Fuck this! End this outdated, 
monarchist institution NOW?!"

The reason male primogeniture existed in the first place because (a) Crown 
princes were expected to lead armies and engage in military actions and (b) 
A huge chunk of the female population died in childbirth. So the more 
children a queen had, the greater the risk to her life. (A king never had 
to fear death by childbirth--if his wife died, he could simply replace her 
with another and carry on.) But radfems will tell you that it was because 
men were meanieheads who didn't want icky girlz in their Clubhouse of 
Patriarchy. Or something like that.... So now eldest girls get to inherit 
the throne! Does that mean they get forced into mandatory military combat 
duty the way their royal fathers and brothers often were (and still are) in 
times of war and peace? Hmmmm?
 ﻿

the sibling will rule as a Regent until the heir comes of age- child kings 
are rare in England, where regency usually takes care of the gaps. The 
sibling themselves will not be king or queen. The pregnant mother will also 
be a Regent- and may use the title Queen Mother, or more safely whatever 
title she owns in her own right- like how Kate is the Duchess of Cambridge 
and Sophie is the Countess of Wessex (William's aunt, married to prince 
Edward)

Actually the modern monarchy is a good model for the second question. When 
Prince Charles becomes King, his heir will always start with Diana's eldest 
son Prince William, even if Charles' new wife Camilla gets a Son.

  There was a loophole that Henry VIII used called 'annulment' which is 
when you pretend the marriage never happened in the first place, however 
this was a Catholic practice (as divorce was not allowed in Catholicism) 
and could not happen anymore after the Church of England was founded.

comments.text:
Considering it's the British monarchy we're talking about i don't 
understand why compromises need to be made about inheriting the throne. If 
you're going to take this long honored tradition and change it for a 
seemingly random reason you might as well change the rule against 
Catholicism. For example if the child was born into a catholic family but 
doesn't believe in it why shouldn't they have a right to the throne? I 
understand the argument for it but then i also understand the argument for 
rule #4 and i still don't agree with it.﻿
comments.author: Crypt Axests

comments.text:
+sada asdafa The ruling didn't come in until a much later date in fact well 
over a century later. Not really anything to do with the Tudors.It was all 
about the fights within the House of Stuart. The ruling came in because 
James VII of Scotland and II of England converted to Catholicism then had a 
baby, James Stuart, the future Old Pretender. The baby had two older 
Protestant sisters, Mary and Anne, but because he was male he was heir to 
the throne so both Scotland and England looked like having a Catholic royal 
dynasty restored. Mary and her husband (William of Orange) were invited by 
some in England to restore the Protestant throne so William invaded England 
and James fled. Once he lost his English power base the Scottish parliament 
branded James a traitor and offered the Scottish throne to William and Mary 
too. They later died without heirs so the younger sister Anne Stuart took 
the throne but she had no heir either so the most obvious next monarch was 
her nephew the exiled James Stuart the Old Pretender. The Scottish 
parliament had passed a law saying that the Scottish monarch needed to be 
both of the Scottish Royal Line and Protestant which paved a way for James 
to return were he to convert from Catholicism. The English Parliament 
looked to exclude James altogether so they passed the law which not only 
excluded Catholics but specifically stated that the future English monarch 
would be Sophie of Hanover and her descendents. Sophie was the daughter of 
Princess Elizabeth of Scotland the elder sister of Charles I. While Anne 
was still alive the union between Scotland and England happened and the 
Hanovarian Succession was one of the articles of the said union treaty 
which created the new united kingdom called Great Britain. In fact that is 
one of the major reasons union came about. The English parliament wanted to 
ensure Scotland chose the same monarch as England. Sophie was already dead 
prior to Anne dying herself so Sophie's son George I became monarch on 
Anne's death.
comments.author: allan connochie

comments.text:
the Act of Sucession (the Act Grey is talking about) specifically removes 
anyone NOT Protestant AND a descendant of Sophie of Hanover- keeping the 
Catholic Church away and within a select line of people.

Previously, post Henry VIII the crown of England passed to Catholic or 
Catholic friendly rulers, some of  whom instigated some really terrible 
crimes against England- the Stuarts waging expensive wars against supposed 
allies, Mary Tudor having killed more people than any monarch in witchhunts 
against Protestants (usually by burning), the Jacobite Rebellion as well as 
the Catholic-supported installation of Mary Queen of Scots up north. Not to 
mention Catholic plots against Elizabeth I , real and imagined. Oliver 
Cromwell's rebellion that unseated Charles I was based partly on a fear of 
control of the country through the Pope.

To tie up sucession in the hands of a single, Protestant dynasty Parliament 
passed the Act, which brought in George I and the beginning of the rule of 
the Hanoverians, who were very un-Catholic.

The attitude even carried on to colonies like the Americas, where parties 
like the Know Nothings and groups lsimilarly the Ku Klux Klan formed partly 
to discriminate against Irish and German immigrants, who they felt would 
give the Pope control over the USA.  The state of Georgia itself was 
initially founded on a motto of "no alcohol, no slaves and no Papists".
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text:
In the end, it boils down to one thing: The Pope. The rule against 
Catholicism was mostly designed (apart from the Head of Anglicanism thing) 
to prevent the Pope having any influence in the Kingdom. This is largely a 
result of the Tudor era when the pope was able to exert his influence on 
whole Kingdoms by various means, including the threat of excommunication 
(which Henry VIII took exception to, admittedly for selfish reasons). This 
is also the reason why, until VERY recently, the monarch was not allowed 
even to marry a Catholic.
